I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In late 2012, the Ministry of Finance and Economic Development (MFED) of Kiribati 
requested  technical  assistance  (TA) from  the  Asian  Development  Bank (ADB) to  continue 
implementation of the government’s state-owned enterprise (SOE) road map, developed with 
ADB assistance. The government’s commitment to SOE reform is articulated in the Kiribati 
Development Plan, 2012–2015 under key policy area 2: economic growth and poverty reduction. 
One  of  the  strategies  identified  is  the  restructuring  of  underperforming  SOEs  to  enhance 
economic  growth  and  improve  living  standards.  This  is  also  a  key  objective  of  Kiribati’s 
structural reform program, as contained in the joint policy matrix developed by the government 
and its development partners. Improving corporate governance and the commercial focus of 
SOEs is a key objective of ADB support identified in the country operations business plan, 
2014–2016 for Kiribati. This focus closely aligns with ADB’s Pacific Approach, which recognizes 
that in a microeconomy, such as Kiribati, poor expenditure allocation decisions have significant 
opportunity costs that impede development and growth.1 
 
2.  The  28  July–1  August  2013  fact-finding  mission  resulted  in  a  memorandum  of 
understanding  with  the  government  outlining  the  agreed  impact,  outcome,  outputs, 
implementation arrangements, and terms of reference for the TA to support the government’s 
SOE  road map. The TA  will  be  provided  in  tandem  with  ongoing  SOE reforms,  including  
(i) introduction of competition in telecommunications; (ii) implementation of a public–private 
partnership for Otintaai Hotel; (iii) negotiations for a potential joint venture between a private 
company from Malaysia and  Betio Shipyard Limited; and (iv) ongoing support to Telecom 
Services Kiribati, Air Kiribati, and the Public Utilities Board. The TA design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1. 2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Kiribati exhibits most of the characteristics and constraints faced by small, vulnerable, 
and fragile countries. Remoteness, small economy, limited resources, and severe capacity 
constraints limit its potential to achieve sustained economic growth and development.  The 
prevailing circumstances mean that the public sector accounts for most of the economy, while 
the private sector is small, underdeveloped, and largely dependent on public sector spending. 
Effective public sector management is thus crucial to ensure that the country’s limited resources 
are directed to where they are needed most. During 2007–2011, the budget deficit (usually 
funded through the Revenue Equalization Reserve Fund) ranged from 13% to 19% of gross 
domestic product, with subsidies to SOEs contributing to the size of the deficit. In 2011, SOEs 
received government support equivalent to about 10% of gross domestic product. Despite the 
support, most SOEs pay no dividends to the government. 
 
4.  The 23 SOEs in the country share common weaknesses: (i) poor financial accounting 
and reporting with financial reports often years in arrears; (ii) lack of clear strategic or business 
plans;  (iii)  no  financial  budget,  or  budgets  that  are  overly  optimistic  and  unachievable;  
(iv) nonpayment of interest or principal on government loans; (v) significant number of unpaid 
creditors and substantial accounts receivable that will never be collected; and (vi) significant 
trading  losses,  with  some  SOEs  technically  insolvent. While  ADB TA  has  helped  improve

governance and financial reporting in some SOEs, more needs to be done to reduce the drain 
on the government budget from underperforming SOEs.3  
 
5.  Poor SOE performance can be attributed to two interrelated factors: 
 
(i)  Absence of a robust legal, governance, and monitoring framework. SOEs 
have been operating without performance targets or accountability for results. No 
professional standards are in place for the appointment of directors. With no 
performance contracts or statements of corporate intent, directors were not held 
accountable. In October 2012, the government enacted the SOE Act, which 
became  effective  on  1  August  2013.  The  act  includes  provisions  for  the 
establishment of basic SOE director duties and obligations, accountability and 
reporting requirements, the roles and obligations of responsible ministers, SOE 
director performance reviews, limitation of the government’s ability to provide 
financial support to SOEs, and establishment of an SOE monitoring unit (SOEMU) 
within the MFED. Implementation of the act will strengthen SOE governance, and 
improve performance and monitoring. 
 
(ii)  Poorly  defined  mandates,  mixing  commercial  with  noncommercial 
activities. In addition to weak governance frameworks, many SOEs do not have 
clear  mandates.  Many  are  required  to  deliver  community  service  obligations 
(CSOs) without consideration of the financial impacts on the SOE. To operate 
efficiently,  SOEs  should  have  very  clear  profit  objectives  and  transparent 
mechanisms to identify, contract, and finance any CSOs. Without these, SOEs 
cannot meet agreed performance targets, and the government cannot ensure 
that it is getting value for money for the CSOs. The lack of a clear commercial 
mandate and of accountability for results are among the main drivers leading to 
poor SOE performance. 
 
6.  In 2008, ADB, with cofinancing from the Government of Australia, provided TA to the 
Government of Kiribati to begin the divestiture of its SOEs, starting with a local hardware trading 
company. Following the successful sale of this SOE, ADB assisted with the sale by competitive 
tender  of  a  wholesale  grocery  and  general  merchandise  trading  company.  The  TA  was 
instrumental in helping the government establish an SOEMU, draft and facilitate the adoption of 
the SOE Act, and develop an SOE reform road map.  
 
7.  The capacity development TA will build on the success of the economic management 
public sector TA, focusing solely on improving SOE performance. Improved SOE performance 
will support economic growth and development. SOE reforms will minimize the fiscal burden of 
inefficient SOEs on the government’s limited resources, allowing the government to better 
allocate resources to productive areas of the economy, including developing and maintaining 
infrastructure and meeting social needs.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The TA impact will be a reduction of the financial demands of underperforming SOEs on 
the government’s fiscal resources. This will be measured by the decrease in fiscal transfers and 
bailouts to SOEs, and a reduction in SOE contingent liabilities. The outcome will be improved 
financial, operating, and governance performance of SOEs. By TA completion, the governance 
framework for SOEs, as established in the SOE Act, will be fully implemented and three SOEs 
will have completed rationalization measures.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The TA will complement ongoing reforms supported by various development partners by 
strengthening SOE governance through implementation of the SOE Act, and by improving 
directors’ performance through implementation of a performance evaluation system. The TA will 
have three outputs: (i) rationalization strategies for three SOEs formulated and implemented, (ii) 
at least four training courses on SOE governance and monitoring delivered, (iii) performance 
evaluation system for SOE directors developed and implemented.  
 
10.  Rationalization strategies for three SOEs formulated and implemented. The TA will 
assist the government in implementing its SOE reform road map. The government has identified 
the Development Bank of Kiribati, Kiribati Ports Authority, Kiribati Insurance Corporation, and Air 
Kiribati as potential SOEs for public–private partnerships. The road map identifies opportunities 
for SOE sales, contracting out, and mergers (such as Kiribati Copra Society and Kiribati Copra 
Mill). The TA, through the SOE Reform Steering Committee (SRSC) will select three SOEs for 
which reforms will be prioritized and matched to available resources. The TA will work closely 
with the ongoing subregional audit support program on the selection of SOEs to ensure that 
accounting and financial report preparation provided by the TA will be consistent. 4 
11.  At least four training courses on SOE governance and monitoring delivered. The 
TA will focus on building the capacity of the SOEMU and the SOEs to improve processes, 
particularly strengthening (i) financial management to help managers effectively manage, plan, 
and  monitor  performance,  and  (ii)  SOE  governance  and  accountability  through  the 
implementation of formal annual processes established under the SOE Act. This output will 
build the capacity of the SOEMU and SOE directors and potential directors to  be able to 
undertake their roles and responsibilities under the act. The TA will review the roles of SOE 
directors  and  provide  training  to  establish  a  pool  of  potential  directors.  The  TA  will  help 
implement the CSO policy through the development of costing methodology for CSOs and CSO 
contracts between SOEs and the government.  
 
12.  Performance evaluation system for SOE directors developed and implemented. 
The TA will work with the SOEMU and shareholding ministries to develop (i) a selection and 
appointment  process  for  directors,  including  a  generic  position  description;  and  (ii)  a 
performance evaluation system to monitor the performance of SOE directors. Shareholding 
ministries will consult with the SOE boards of directors, the SOEMU, and responsible ministers 
before implementing the system.

C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $880,000, of which $800,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, and administered by ADB. The government will 
provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  counterpart  staff,  office  accommodation,  office 
supplies,  and  other  in-kind  contributions.  The  cost  estimates  and  financing  plan  are  in  
Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  As the executing agency, MFED will appoint a TA focal point person to oversee activities 
of the consulting team and maintain the exchange of information. The consultants will, with the 
TA  focal  point  person,  liaise  with  relevant  development  partner  programs  and  projects  to 
promote coordination and complementarity of activities. To promote sustainability, the TA will 
use the SRSC formed under the Economic Management and Public Sector Reform TA, chaired 
by  the  secretary  of  finance  and  comprising  officials  from  MFED,  the  line  ministries,  and 
representatives  from  nongovernment  organizations  and  the  private  sector.  The  steering 
committee will promote broad-based commitment to the direction of reforms and guide TA 
implementation.  
 
15.  Lessons from previous assistance to MFED used in the TA design include (i) using a 
national  committee  to  direct  TA  implementation;  (ii)  ensuring  that  consultant  missions  are 
undertaken  when  local  counterparts  are  in  the  country;  (iii)  using  a  good  local  facilitator;  
(iv) focusing first on updating SOE financial accounts and land leasing arrangements; and  
(v) stressing the importance of earning the government’s trust and confidence. Based on these, 
the TA will continue to rely on the SRSC to direct TA implementation. Given the importance of 
resolving land issues at the earliest possible time, a representative from the lands department 
will be appointed to the SRSC. Due to the lack of qualified accountants in the country and to 
avoid delays, the TA will engage an international SOE accounting specialist to update the 
financial accounts of three SOEs to enable the TA team to undertake due diligence of the best 
rationalization option for the selected SOEs. 
 
16.  The TA will be implemented from 1 December 2013 to 31 December 2016. It is expected 
to finance 20 person-months of intermittent international consulting and 10 person-months of 
national  consulting  services  (Appendix  3).  The  consultant  team  will  have  an  SOE  reform 
specialist  and  team  leader  (10  person-months),  an  SOE  accounting  specialist  (3  person-
months),  an  SOE  legal  specialist  (4  person-months),  and  a  capacity  building  specialist  (3 
person-months). A national SOE specialist (10 person-months) will assist the international team. 
International  consultants  will  be  senior  technical  specialists  in  their  field  with  extensive 
experience in small island states. The consultants will be selected and engaged through a firm 
based on a simplified technical proposal under the quality- and cost-based selection process, 
using a 90:10 weighting for quality and cost. ADB will engage the consultants according to the 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). Proceeds of the 
TA will be disbursed in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook 
(2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
17.  The consultants will produce a concise inception report outlining the work program and 
milestones for the duration of the TA, and a final report summarizing the achievements, issues, 
lessons, and next steps. Throughout the TA, the consultants will submit (by e-mail) brief monthly 
progress reports summarizing TA activities, progress, issues, and constraints. The draft final 
report will be submitted at least 5 weeks prior to the end of the assignment, and the final report

5 
within 2 weeks of receipt of government and ADB comments. 
 
18.  TA progress will be monitored using intended outcomes and outputs described in the 
design and monitoring framework (Appendix 1). ADB will assist the government in providing all 
reports to the development partners. The reports will be disseminated through round-table 
meetings, radio interviews, and the ADB website. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 to the Government 
of  Kiribati  to  be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  the  Japan  Fund  for  Poverty  Reduction  for 
Enhancing Economic Competitiveness through State-Owned Enterprise Reform, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Consultant services will support the three outputs of this technical assistance (TA). The 
team leader, who will be a state-owned enterprise (SOE) reform specialist, will supervise the TA. 
The consultants will work closely together to ensure the TA is in line with the proposed scope. 
The TA will work closely with 3 SOEs, which the government will select from the 23 SOEs.   
 
2.  The TA will conduct at least four training workshops to develop the capacity of the State-
Owned Enterprise Monitoring Unit (SOEMU), SOE management teams, and SOE boards of 
directors. The workshops will target existing boards of directors and potential directors, and 
focus  on  the  SOE  Act,  financial  reporting  and  SOE  accounting  standards,  directors’ 
responsibilities and roles stipulated under the SOE Act, the calculation of community service 
obligations (CSOs), corporate planning, development of Statement Of Intents, and performance 
management and evaluation. The 1-week workshops will each target 40–50 participants. 
 
3.  SOE reform specialist and team leader (international, 10 person-months, intermittent). 
The consultant will (i) have extensive experience in SOE reform and enterprise development 
across a range of geographic, technical, and, possibly, political settings; (ii) be able to meet all 
the  broad  technical  government  and  enterprise  development  requirements  competently;  
(iii) have demonstrated strong political, negotiation, and process facilitation skills; and (iv) have 
practical understanding of consultative and participatory processes. Work experience in Kiribati, 
especially with SOEs and/or the SOEMU, Ministry of Finance and Economic Development, is 
highly desirable. The responsibilities of the consultant include the following: 
 
(i)  Develop a detailed work plan to implement priority TA elements. The work plan is 
to be endorsed by ADB and the government.  
(ii)  Work closely with the SOE Reform Steering Committee (SRSC) to identify at 
least three SOEs for rationalization. 
(iii)  Work closely with the accounting specialist to update the financial accounts of 
selected SOEs with priority to SOEs selected for rationalization. 
(iv)  Work closely with the SRSC and the SOEMU to develop rationalization strategies 
for the selected SOEs. 
(v)  Assist the SOEMU in implementing the rationalization strategies. 
(vi)  Work together with the SOEMU and capacity building specialist to (a) develop a 
selection  and  appointment  process  for  directors,  including  development  of 
generic position descriptions; and (b) develop and implement a performance 
evaluation and monitoring system for directors. 
(vii)  Advise the government, with the assistance of the national SOE specialist, on the 
strategy to retain employees and social cohesion, including proposals for such 
methods as management buy-in, management contract, or appropriate social 
safeguard options. 
(viii)  Assist the capacity building specialist in developing and implementing capacity 
building materials for SOE directors, SOE management, and the SOEMU. 
(ix)  Coordinate with development partner(s) and relevant specialists providing related 
assistance. 
(x)  Support the local SOE specialist in the conduct of a public awareness campaign, 
public consultation, and information dissemination on key aspects of the TA work. 
(xi)  Work closely with the SOEMU to implement the CSO requirement of the SOE Act. 
(xii)  Maintain close contact with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) project officer 
and the executing agencies during TA implementation.

10  Appendix 3 
(xiii)  Prepare knowledge products (policy briefs on lessons, TA experiences, and best 
practices) for use outside of Kiribati and support the government in raising public 
awareness on the importance of SOE reform. 
(xiv)  Perform  overall  TA management and  coordinate  with  ADB,  the government, 
development partners, and other stakeholders to ensure that the TA milestones 
are met. 
(xv)  Collate and prepare inception, half-yearly, draft final, and final reports for the TA 
as a whole, as required by ADB. Prepare end of mission reports.  
(xvi)  Help with other tasks to ensure successful implementation of the proposed public 
enterprise reforms. 
 
4.  SOE  legal  specialist  (international,  4  person-months,  intermittent).  The  specialist 
should have a tertiary qualification in law, be familiar with SOE acts in small island countries, 
have  experience  in  drafting  sale  and  purchase  agreements  for  the  sale  of  SOEs,  and 
understand public–private partnership arrangements. The specialist’s responsibilities include the 
following:  
 
(i)  Prepare, in conjunction with the SOE reform specialist, a request for expressions 
of interest in buying the SOE to be privatized. 
(ii)  Prepare  a  draft  sale  and  purchase  agreement  in  consultation  with  the  SOE 
reform specialist, including dispute resolution provisions. In preparing this draft, 
liaise  closely  with  the  SOE  reform  specialist  to  assess  whether  any  as  yet 
unidentified legal issues need to be addressed in the draft.  
(iii)  Prepare, in conjunction with the SOE reform specialist, a heads of agreement 
that sets out the basis for the sale and purchase of the SOE (including the draft 
sale and purchase agreement), government’s approach to the sale process, and 
envisaged timetable and dispute resolution process. This agreement is for joint 
signature by (a) respondents to the request for expressions of interest, who 
confirm their intention to engage in the sale, and (b) the vendor.  
(iv)  Prepare  a  draft  confidentiality  deed—to  protect  the  vendor’s  interests—for 
potential buyers to sign before they may undertake a due diligence inspection of 
the  SOE’s  accounts,  related  documents,  and  operations,  for  the  purpose  of 
determining what if any offer to make for the SOE.  
(v)  Prepare, in consultation with the SOE reform specialist, a due diligence protocol 
to govern the buyers due diligence inspection for signature by potential buyers 
before they may engage in the due diligence inspection process. 
(vi)  Assess the legal implications of offers to purchase the SOE, and how best to 
respond to them and advise the vendor accordingly on the overall merits of such 
offers.  
(vii)  If a sale is agreed, help the government with the settlement process as required.  
(viii)  Assist  in  drafting the  standard  CSO  agreements  and  other  legal  documents 
required by the TA. 
 
5.  SOE accounting specialist (international, 3 person-months, intermittent). The specialist 
should  (i)  hold  a  recognized  professional  accountancy  qualification,  (ii)  have  extensive 
experience in the application of International Financial Reporting Standards  in the preparation 
of financial statements for SOEs, (iii) have a background appropriate to undertake the assigned 
tasks, and (iv) have at least 10 years practical experience and significant experience specific to 
small island states. The specialist’s tasks will include the following:

 (i)  Support the SOE reform and privatization process by obtaining the following from 
each SOE: (a) reliable financial statements; (b) reliable current information on 
staff  establishment,  employment  status,  wage  rates  and/or  wages  bill,  and 
employment history; (c) an updated, comprehensive fixed assets register; and  
 (d) an accurate list of debtors and creditors. 
(ii)  Collaborate with the SOE reform specialist and the national SOE specialist, as 
necessary, in the continuing process of restructuring, reforming or disposing of 
designated SOEs. 
(iii)  Update the financial accounts of selected SOEs based on available information. 
(iv)   Assist the team in undertaking due diligence of the best rationalization option for 
the selected SOEs. 
(v)  Prepare  a template for  SOE  use for financial  reporting  to  management  and 
boards of directors. 
(vi)  Assist  the  SOEMU,  relevant  line  ministries,  and  SOEs,  as  appropriate,  to 
implement use of the financial reporting template. 
(vii)  Provide training as appropriate to MFED, line ministries, and SOE personnel on 
the use of the financial reporting template.  
(viii)  Provide inputs to all TA reports as required and support the team leader and 
other team members as required. 
 
6.  Capacity building specialist (international, 3 person-months, intermittent). The expert 
will be efficient in facilitation and education; have at least 10 years of experience providing 
similar advice to a variety of Pacific governments and societies; and have demonstrated strong 
political,  negotiation,  and  process  facilitation  skills.  Knowledge  of  SOE  monitoring  and 
performance evaluation systems is important. Tasks will include the following: 
 
(i)  Work  closely  with  the  SOE  reform  specialist  to  develop  capacity  building 
materials  for  the  SOEMU,  SOE  management,  and  SOE  directors  based  on 
requirements of the SOE Act. 
(ii)  Develop job descriptions, and selection and evaluation systems for boards of 
directors. 
(iii)  Develop capacity building materials for the SOEMU on selecting directors and 
evaluating SOE director performance. 
(iv)  Provide  a  framework  for  ownership,  monitoring,  capacity  development  and 
training  in  areas  identified  in  item  (i),  including  a  monitoring  framework  to 
measure the impact of individual interventions and baseline competency for the 
various capacity development areas. The expert will take the lead in designing 
and  implementing  training,  seminars,  and  conferences  based  on  the  areas 
identified in items (i) and (ii). 
(v)  Lead and undertake capacity development activities agreed under items (i) and 
(ii) and included in the framework developed under item (iii). 
(vi)  Provide input for TA reports as requested by the team leader. 
 
7.  SOE specialist (national, 10 person-months, intermittent). The specialist will have a 
strong background in training, education, and consultative and participatory processes, as well 
as extensive experience in technical assistance in those fields in small island states. The  
specialist will work under the guidance of the team leader and specialists. Responsibilities will 
include the following: 
 
(i)  Liaise  directly  with  government  counterparts  in  the  Ministry  of  Finance  and 
Economic  Development,  other  line  ministries  as  appropriate,  and  any

12  Appendix 3 
government units established to support the SOE reform process to identify SOE 
requirements and the progress of SOE reform.  
(ii)  Liaise directly with SOE boards and SOE staff as appropriate to ensure progress 
of SOE reform, including identifying and extracting key information and data to 
support the reform and/or sale process.  
(iii)  Work with the international SOE consulting team to determine the best way to 
ensure progress of the SOE reform process and assist in implementing agreed 
tasks.  
(iv)  Provide inputs to all TA reports. 
 
8.  The consultants will prepare an inception report for ADB and the government within  
8 weeks of the start of field activities. It will include the capacity development road map. Half-
yearly progress reports will be submitted during TA implementation and a draft final report by 
December 2016. The final report is to be submitted within a month of the incorporation of ADB 
and the government comments on the draft final report.
